sentences.segment_text: Severe acute respiratory syndrome ( SARS ) is characterized by substantial acute pulmonary inflammation with a high mortality rate .
Despite the identification of SARS coronavirus ( SARS-CoV ) as the etiologic agent of SARS ,
a thorough understanding of the underlying disease pathogenesis has been hampered by the lack of a suitable animal model that recapitulates the human disease .

abstract.original_text: H-2 k mice demonstrated moderate susceptibility, with C3H/HeJ mice exhibiting the most severe disease. C3H/HeJ mice harbor a natural mutation in the gene that encodes Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) that disrupts TLR4 signaling. C3H/HeJ mice exhibit enhanced morbidity and mortality following i.n. MHV-1 infection compared to wild-type C3H/HeN mice. Our results indicate that TLR4 plays an important role in respiratory CoV pathogenesis.
